sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: Moving the various trauma and stress-related disorders into a chapter of their own in the DSM-5 was a significant step indicating that the etiology of these disorders was stress rather than mood. Moreover, adding Prolonged Grief Disorder recently to the DSM-5-TR suggests that the Trauma and Stress-Related Disorders chapter on the DSM is still developing and evolving. The distress resulting from both traumatic experiences and other stressors reflects a way of processing the trauma, albeit in a dysfunctional way. Trauma and stress-related disorders are complex, multi-faceted, and often more challenging to diagnose than depression or anxiety. Different people can endorse completely different symptoms (e. g., hyperarousal versus avoidance, anger versus shame) and experience different comorbid disorders (e. g., depression versus substance use) and still meet DSM-5 criteria for a PTSD diagnosis. In the past two decades, we have witnessed a growing body of research on scientifically supported psychotherapies for PTSD, such as EMDR, PET, and CPT. These psychotherapies are now considered first-line treatments for PTSD. However, we are also seeing the emergence of a new, exciting, and promising body of research in the form of psychedelic-assisted therapy for PTSD (e. g., MDMA-assisted therapy). The diagnosis and treatment of such disorders require well-trained and skilled mental health clinicians who possess working knowledge about trauma disorders and use evidence-based practices.
